tn.text: Chapters 7 and 8 are not in chronological order. They happened while Belshazzar was still the king, before the rule of Darius and Cyrus that was discussed in chapter 6.
In Daniel's vision, he saw animals that were symbols of other things. Later in the vision someone explains the meaning of those symbols. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])
This was the name of Nebuchadnezzar's son, who became king after him. See how you wrote this name in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:05:01|5:1]].
The words "dream" and "visions" both refer to the same dream that is described in this chapter. AT: "visions while he was dreaming" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"winds from everywhere" or "strong winds from all four directions" (UDB)
"whipped up" or "agitated" or "caused high waves in"

tn.ref: The first was like a lion but had eagle's wings
tn.text: This was a symbolic creature, and not an animal that exists. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage|Symbolic Language]])

tn.ref: its wings were torn off and it was lifted from the ground and made to stand on two feet, like a man
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone tore off its wings and lifted it up from the ground and made it stand on two feet like a human being" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])

tn.ref: The mind of a man was given to it
tn.text: Here "mind" refers to thinking. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Someone gave it the ability to think like a human being" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy|Metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])

tn.ref: a second animal, like a bear
tn.text: This was not an actual bear, but a symbolic animal that was similar to a bear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage|Symbolic Language]])
large curved bones of the chest that connect to the spine
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Someone told it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])

tn.ref: another animal, one that looked like a leopard
tn.text: This was not an actual leopard, but a symbolic animal that was similar to a leopard. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])
The four wings and four heads are symbols, but their meaning is unclear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])
"the animal had four heads"

tn.ref: It was given authority to rule
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Someone gave it authority to rule" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: a fourth animal ... it had ten horns
tn.text: This is also not an actual animal. It is a symbolic creature. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])
"walked on and crushed"
Daniel continues to describe his vision of the fourth animal that the saw in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:07:06|7:7]].
Translators may write a footnote like this: "Horns are a symbol of power and represent powerful leaders." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Three of the first horns were wrenched out by the roots
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The little horn tore out three of the first horns" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: a mouth that was boasting about great things
tn.text: Here the horn was boasting, using its mouth to do so. AT: "the horn had a mouth and boasted about doing great things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Most of the text of verses 9-14 is symbolic language with parallel lines that have similar meaning. For this reason, the ULB and UDB present them in poetic form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone set thrones in their places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a title for God that means he is eternal. AT: "the One Who Has Lived Forever" or "the One Who Has Always Lived"

tn.ref: took his seat ... His clothing ... the hair of his head
tn.text: This passage describes God as sitting down, with clothing and hair like a person. This does not mean that God really is like this, but it is how Daniel saw God in a vision.
This is an idiom that means he sat down. AT: "sat down on his throne" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: His clothing was as white as snow
tn.text: His clothing is compared to snow to show that it was very white. AT: "His clothing was very white"

tn.ref: the hair of his head was like pure wool
tn.text: Something about God's hair looked like pure wool. Possible meanings are that 1) it was very white (UDB) or 2) it was thick and curly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"clean wool" or "wool that is washed"

tn.ref: His throne was flames ... its wheels were burning fire
tn.text: This describes the throne of God and its wheels as if they were made of fire. The words "flames" and "burning fire" mean basically the same thing and can be translated the same way.

It is unclear why God's throne is described as having wheels. Thrones normally do not have wheels, but the text clearly states that this throne has some kind of wheels. Use a general term for "wheels" if possible.
Daniel continues to describe his vision of the court in heaven and the response to the fourth animal that he saw in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:07:06|7:7]].

Most of the text of verses 9-14 is symbolic language with parallel lines that have similar meaning. For this reason, the ULB and UDB present them in poetic form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: A river of fire flowed out from before him
tn.text: The quick way in which fire came from the presence of God is spoken of as if it was water flowing in a river. AT: "Fire poured out in front of him like water in a river" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "him" refers to God, the Ancient of Days from [[:en:bible:notes:dan:07:09|7:9]].
This probably refers to a large group rather than to a precise number. AT: "thousands of thousands" or "great numbers of people"
This probably refers to a large group rather than to a precise number. AT: "tens of thousands times tens of thousands" or "uncountable numbers of people"
This means that God, the judge, was ready to investigate the evidence and make his judgment. AT: "The judge was ready to judge" or "The judge was seated"
These are the books that contain the evidence to be used in court. AT: "the books of evidence were opened"
Daniel continues to describe his vision of the court in heaven and the response to the fourth animal that he saw in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:07:06|7:7]].

tn.ref: the animal was killed ... to be burned up
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "they killed the fourth animal, destroyed its body, and gave it to someone to burn it up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

The animal was killed because the judge determined that it was guilty. AT: "they executed the animal" or "the judge commanded and they killed the animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to the fourth animal that had the ten horns and the horn that spoke boastfully. AT: "the most frightening animal" or "the animal that had the boastful horn"

tn.ref: the rest of the four animals
tn.text: It may be clearer to say, "the other three animals."

tn.ref: their authority to rule was taken away
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the judge took away their authority to rule" or "their authority to rule ended" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: their lives were prolonged for a period of time
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "they continued to live for a period of time" or "the judge let them live a little longer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Most of the text of verses 9-14 is symbolic language with parallel lines that have similar meaning. For this reason, the ULB and UDB present them in poetic form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: I saw one coming ... like a son of man
tn.text: The person that Daniel saw was not a normal man, but had a human figure like a man. "I also saw that night someone coming who resembled a son of man, that is, he had a human figure" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"with the clouds of the sky"
This refers to God who is eternal. See how you translated this title in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:07:09|7:9]]
This can be stated in active form. AT: "they presented this son of man to the Ancient of Days" or "he stood before him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Authority to rule and glory and royal power were given to him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The one who looked like a son of man received authority to rule, glory, and royal power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This, here, refers to "authority."

Here "nations" and "languages" represent people from different nations who speak different languages. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:03:03|3:4]]. AT: "people from different nations and who speak different languages" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: will not pass away ... will never be destroyed
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "that no one will ever destroy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: my spirit was grieved inside of me ... the visions I saw in my mind troubled me
tn.text: These two phrases describe how Daniel was feeling. The second one gives more information about the first one, explaining about his grieved spirit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: my spirit was grieved inside of me
tn.text: Here "my spirit" refers to Daniel himself. AT: "I was very sad inside" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is one of the heavenly beings who were standing before God's throne (UDB). Possible meanings 1) these are angels, spirits who serve God 2) these are people who have died and are now in heaven.
"to tell me" (UDB) or "to explain to me"
"the things I had seen"

tn.ref: These large animals, four in number,
tn.text: "These four large animals"
"represent four kings"

tn.ref: four kings that will arise from the earth
tn.text: Here "from the earth" means they are real people. AT: "four kings who will come to power on the earth" (UDB) or "four men who will rise up from among the people of the earth and become kings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"they will rule over it"
This repetition of ideas emphasizes that this kingdom will never come to an end. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"very frightening"
"walked on and crushed"

tn.ref: the ten horns on its head
tn.text: "the ten horns on the head of the fourth animal"

tn.ref: grew up, and before which the three horns fell down
tn.text: "grew up, and about the three horns that fell down in front of it" or "grew up, and about the three horns that fell down because of it"

tn.ref: before which the three horns fell down
tn.text: Here "fell down" is a euphemism that means they were destroyed." AT: "which destroyed the three horns" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"its mouth that boasted" or "the mouth of the new horn, that boasted"

tn.ref: that seemed greater than its companions
tn.text: the horn with the eyes and a mouth seemed to be greater than the other horns
"this fourth horn." This refers to the horn that is described in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:07:19|7:20]].

tn.ref: until the Ancient of Days came, and justice was given
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "until the Ancient of Days came and brought justice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a title for God that emphasizes that he is eternal. See how you translated this title in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:07:09|7:9]].

tn.ref: the holy people received the kingdom
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God gave his kingdom to his holy people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Most of the text of verses 23-27 is symbolic language. For this reason, the ULB presents them in poetic form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])

tn.ref: This is what that person said
tn.text: This is the person that Daniel approached in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:07:15|7:16]].
"that person answered"

tn.ref: As for the fourth animal ... As for the ten horns
tn.text: "Concerning the fourth animal ... Concerning the ten horns" or "Now, about the fourth animal ... Now, about the ten horns"

tn.ref: It will devour ... it into pieces
tn.text: This does not mean the fourth kingdom will destroy the planet, but that it will brutally attack, conquer, and destroy all other kingdoms on earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: out of this kingdom ten kings will arise
tn.text: They will rule one after the other. This can be stated explicitly. AT: "ten kings will rule over this fourth kingdom, one after another" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This other king is not one of the ten. It may be helpful to refer to him as "the eleventh king." AT: "after that an eleventh king will become powerful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: He will be different from the previous ones
tn.text: "He will be different from the other ten kings"

tn.ref: he will conquer the three kings
tn.text: He will defeat three of the original ten kings. It may be helpful to state that those three kings are represented by the three horns that were pulled out. AT: "he will defeat the three kings that were represented by the three horns that were pulled out" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The man in Daniel's vision continues talking to Daniel.
Most of the text of verses 23-27 is symbolic language. For this reason, the ULB presents them in poetic form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])

tn.ref: He will speak words against the Most High
tn.text: This means that the newest king will openly disagree with and say bad things about the Most High. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: He will try ... into his hand
tn.text: The words "He" and "his" refer to the newest king, not the Most High.
"God's holy people"

tn.ref: change the festivals and the law
tn.text: Both terms refer to the law of Moses. The festivals were an important part of the religion of Israel in the Old Testament.

tn.ref: These things will be given into his hand
tn.text: Here "his hand" refers to his control. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The newest king will control the religous festivals and laws" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: one year, two years, and half a year
tn.text: This means "three and half years" (UDB). This is not the normal way the Israelites counted. Try to translate it in a way that preserves this way of counting. AT: "one year plus two years plus six months"

tn.ref: the court will be in session
tn.text: This means that the judge will be ready to investigate evidence and make his judgment. AT: "the judge will judge" or "The judge will sit down"

tn.ref: they will take his royal power away
tn.text: "the members of the court will take the royal power away from the newest king"
This, here, refers to "authority." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:07:13|7:14]].

tn.ref: to be consumed and destroyed at the end
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "and consume and destroy it in the end" or "and completely destroy his royal power in the end" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The man in Daniel's vision continues talking to Daniel.
Most of the text of verses 23-27 is symbolic language. For this reason, the ULB presents them in poetic form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])

tn.ref: The kingdom and the dominion ... will be given to the people
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will give the kingdom and the dominion ... to the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These two terms mean basically the same thing and emphasize that this will concern all forms of official authority. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The abstract noun "greatness" can be translated with the adjective "great." AT: "everything that is great about the kingdoms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: of the kingdoms under the whole heaven
tn.text: The idiom "under the whole heaven"  refers to the kingdoms on earth. AT: "of all the kingdoms on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"The kingdom of the Most High"
"a kingdom that will exist forever" or "a kingdom that will never end"

tn.ref: Here is the end of the matter
tn.text: This means that Daniel has finished describing the vision. AT: "That is what I saw in my vision" (UDB) or "This is the end of the description of what I saw in my vision"
"my face became pale"
